awd_titl_txt: EDU: Lightweight Environment for Network Security Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop a lightweight infrastructure for supporting hands-on network security education (NSE) and a compelling set of exercises that rely on the infrastructure, covering the three basic aspects of the security: attack, analysis, and defense. Historically, building realistic Cybersecurity exercises has been both a laborious and resource-intensive task. Over the course of a semester, the number of virtual machines (VM) and snapshots on the server can easily become hundreds or thousands, which imposes serious maintenance overhead on the instructor and systems administration staff Finally, once created, the VMs are relatively large and are not easily shareable across the Internet, thereby effectively limiting the exchange of materials among educators. The project proposes a solution to fundamentally change how Cybersecurity exercises are created and delivered by creating a flexible Cybersecurity education infrastructure based on lightweight virtualization containers. The Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program funds proposals that address Cybersecurity from a Trustworthy Computing Systems perspective; a Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences perspective; and proposals focusing entirely on Cybersecurity Education.

The broader impacts of the project include vastly increasing the availability of tested, applied Cybersecurity exercises while reducing the need for complex and hard-to-manage hardware environments, allowing instructors to focus on course content and pedagogy rather than on system administration. It proposes to leverage Linux container technology and the docker tool that facilitates container use. It proposes to create two seed instances: secure programming via SQL injections; and network defense via data exfiltration. These two pre-loaded instances can be used as lab exercises or as examples of how to use this architecture.

por.por_cntn:
The main contribution of this work is the development of a lightweight infrastructure, LENSE, which supports the development, management, and deployment of cybersecurity exercises. The system has minimal resource requirements and easily be deployed in a classroom setting. The implementation utilizes Docker containers and Ansible configuration management to provide a layer of automation and abstraction, which obviates the need for an instructor using the system to understand (in detail) how to manage containers.

By employing Docker’s registry service, the infrastructure provides de facto standard means for efficient sharing of materials. Most existing environments can be containerized with a fairly modest effort. The use of Ansible has proven to be a sound design choice as it adds robustness and recoverability to the infrastructure in the face of multiple possible failures, and is sufficiently lightweight to not measurably decrease performance.  

The performance evaluation shows that, consistent with our original hypothesis, the employment of containers affords a much smaller resource footprint for deploying complex hands-on security exercises. For example, the initial download and launch of a representative scenario over a commidity Ethernet network requires 75 seconds for 16 machines; observed subsequent restarts complete within 18 seconds, regardless of the number of student machines. 

The presented results are under peer review and are being incorporated as part of follow-up cybersecurity education projects, both by NSF and other funding agencies. In particular, we expect LENSE to serve as the core to more advanced teaching environments, including the use of AI agents to simulate large-scale realistic exercises.

Among the broader impacts, we expect to tailor the LENSE environment to both other aspects of security education, such as ICS/SCADA coursework, as well as, to other senior/graduate courses in the Computer Science curriculum. We expect to deploy the platform to a cluster of raspberry PI devices for outreach efforts providing an affordable classroom-in-a-box solution.
